elements.content: Trivalent lanthanide ions combined with two molecular linkers, organic 4,4′-azopyridine-1,1′-dioxide (apdo), and inorganic hexacyanidocobaltate­(III), gave a series of magnetoluminescent coordination polymers, [{LnIII(apdo)­(H2O)4}­{CoIII(CN)6}]·2H2O (Ln = Nd, 1; Tb, 2; Dy, 3; Er, 4; Tm, 5; Yb, 6). They are hybrid organic–inorganic layered frameworks composed of cyanido-bridged {Ln2(μ-NC)4Co2} squares linked by Ln–apdo–Ln bridges into a coordination network of a mixed 4- and 8-metal ring topology. Lanthanide­(III) complexes, [LnIII(μ-apdo)2(H2O)4(μ-NC)2]+, of a distorted dodecahedral geometry are isolated by diamagnetic [CoIII(CN)6]3– and apdo linkers. As a result, 1–6 reveal field-induced slow relaxation of magnetization, with typical temperature-dependent relaxation of a single-ion origin for NdIII-containing 1, DyIII-containing 3, and YbIII-containing 6. The related alternate-current magnetic data were precisely analyzed, indicating the multiple magnetic relaxation pathways, including a direct process, strong quantum tunneling of magnetization, non-negligible Raman processes, and crucial two-phonon Orbach thermal relaxation. The thermal energy barriers of the Orbach process, ΔE/k B, are 15.1(9) K with τ0 = 9.8(9) × 10–6 s at H dc = 4500 Oe, 16.1(8) K with τ0 = 9.0(9) × 10–5 s at H dc = 1500 Oe, and 17.3(6) K with τ0 = 3.2(7) × 10–6 s at H dc = 700 Oe, for 1, 3, and 6, respectively, proving the single-molecule magnet (SMM) behavior. Because of the presence of [Co­(CN)6]3–, 1–6 show strong UV absorption, while the chromophoric apdo leads to the strong absorption in the visible range. As a result, the visible 4f/3d metal-centered emission is quenched, but the near-infrared luminescence from NdIII and YbIII is observed in 1 and 6, respectively. It is realized by Co-to-Ln metal-to-metal, and apdo-to-Ln ligand-to-metal energy transfers; thus, broad UV-to-visible excitation can be explored. Compounds 1–6 form a novel family of functional bimetallic assemblies, incorporating NIR-emissive SMMs as presented for NdCo (1) and YbCo (6) derivatives.

elements.content: The organic 4,4′-azopyridine-1,1′-dioxide ligand and inorganic hexacyanidocobaltate­(III) ion work together as two coexisting molecular bridges in novel heterometallic d−f layered frameworks. The NdCo and YbCo derivatives combine magnetic anisotropy leading to field-induced slow relaxation of magnetization with the sensitized near-infrared photoluminescence produced by the broad-range UV-to-visible light excitation, thanks to the ligand-to-metal and metal-to-metal energy transfer processes.

The NdCo and YbCo derivatives combine magnetic anisotropy leading to field-induced slow relaxation of magnetization with the sensitized near-infrared photoluminescence produced by the broad-range UV-to-visible light excitation, thanks to the ligand-to-metal and metal-to-metal energy transfer processes.

elements.content: Within modern coordination chemistry strongly aimed at the preparation of novel materials exhibiting various magnetic, optical, electric, and sorption properties, we are witnessing the continuously growing scientific interest in exploration of rare earth metal ions. Of a special interest are trivalent lanthanide complexes showing efficient photoluminescence due to their f–f electronic transitions which produce the emission from UV (Gd3+) to visible (Eu3+, Tb3+, Sm3+, Dy3+) to near-infrared (Nd3+, Er3+, Yb3+) ranges. This opens several vital applications in light-emitting devices, optical communication, low-energy scintillation, optical storage, chemical sensing, bioimaging, high-resolution thermometry, photovoltaics, and light conversion.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Within modern coordination chemistry strongly aimed at the preparation of novel materials exhibiting various magnetic, optical, electric, and sorption properties, we are witnessing the continuously growing scientific interest in exploration of rare earth metal ions. Of a special interest are trivalent lanthanide complexes showing efficient photoluminescence due to their f-f electronic transitions which produce the emission from UV (Gd3+) to visible (Eu3+, Tb3+, Sm3+, Dy3+) to near-infrared (Nd3+, Er3+, Yb3+) ranges. This opens several vital applications in light-emitting devices, optical communication, low-energy scintillation, optical storage, chemical sensing, bioimaging, high-resolution thermometry, photovoltaics, and light conversion.

elements.content: In the past few years, it was shown that lanthanide­(3+) complexes are great candidates for high-density information storage and processing devices thanks to their remarkably strong magnetic anisotropy. Paramagnetic 4f metal ions embedded in the specific coordination geometries, ensuring appropriate charge distribution, reveal significant single-ion anisotropy which produces slow relaxation of magnetization related to the thermal energy barrier (ΔE) of spin inversion. Below blocking temperature, magnetic relaxation of such molecules, called single-molecule magnets (SMMs), is so slow that the magnetic hysteresis loop of a molecular origin can be detected. Lanthanide-based SMMs were found within the coordination clusters of 4f metal centers, or their mixed polynuclear molecules with d-block metal ions. However, the greatest achievements were reached for mononuclear 4f metal complexes, especially Dy3+ and Tb3+, with the highest magnetic blocking below 60 K for the dysprosocenium complex.

elements.content: By precise selection of 4f metal ions and supporting ligands, it was possible to achieve the lanthanide­(III) complexes combining luminescence and magnetic anisotropy. This scientific pathway contributed greatly to the emerging trend of multifunctionality, explored efficiently for molecule-based magnets linking magnetic effects with chirality, ferroelectricity, or photoinduced phase transitions. Bifunctional emissive single-molecule magnets have been fabricated using mononuclear 4f metal complexes of highly anisotropic DyIII, ErIII, and YbIII centers with attached organic ligands enhancing their photoluminescence within the antenna effect.

This scientific pathway contributed greatly to the emerging trend of multifunctionality, explored efficiently for molecule-based magnets linking magnetic effects with chirality, ferroelectricity, or photoinduced phase transitions. Bifunctional emissive single-molecule magnets have been fabricated using mononuclear 4f metal complexes of highly anisotropic DyIII, ErIII, and YbIII centers with attached organic ligands enhancing their photoluminescence within the antenna effect.

elements.content: Lately, luminescent single-molecule magnets have been achieved in lanthanide-based metal–organic frameworks (LnMOFs). Rational design of organic ligands for construction of MOFs enables the efficient constraining of the coordination geometry of lanthanide­(III) which can govern their magnetic anisotropy toward high thermal energy barriers. On the other hand, a considerable number of luminescent MOFs were presented, with a variety of optical effects, including tunable white light and multicolored emission, or upconversion. With a combination of these two approaches, LnMOFs were able to exhibit luminescence and slow magnetic relaxation; however, very few examples of such bifunctional coordination polymers were presented.
elements.clean_text: Lately, luminescent single-molecule magnets have been achieved in lanthanide-based metal-organic frameworks (LnMOFs). Rational design of organic ligands for construction of MOFs enables the efficient constraining of the coordination geometry of lanthanide(III) which can govern their magnetic anisotropy toward high thermal energy barriers. On the other hand, a considerable number of luminescent MOFs were presented, with a variety of optical effects, including tunable white light and multicolored emission, or upconversion. With a combination of these two approaches, LnMOFs were able to exhibit luminescence and slow magnetic relaxation; however, very few examples of such bifunctional coordination polymers were presented.

elements.content: Within the broad family of coordination polymers, heterometallic cyanido-bridged networks incorporating lanthanide­(3+) ions have appeared as an attractive tool for generation of strong photoluminescence, and magnetic anisotropy. Cyanide d-block metal complexes were found to be good sensitizers for 4f metal ions as exemplified by linear dicyanidometallates, [MI(CN)2]− (M = Ag, Au), and square planar tetracyanidometallates, [MII(CN)4]2– (M = Pd, Pt), efficiently enhancing visible luminescence of Eu3+ or Tb3+ by metal-to-metal energy transfer process. On the contrary, low-lying charge transfer states of heteroligand tetracyanidometallates, [MII(CN)4(L)]2– (M = Ru, Os) are suitable for sensitization of near-infrared emission of Nd3+ and Yb3+. Polycyanidometallates were also explored as molecular components for magnetically anisotropic systems revealing single-molecule magnet (SMM), or analogous single-chain magnet (SCM), behavior, within heterometallic d–d, and d–f coordination systems. In particular, paramagnetic hexacyanidometallates, [MIII(CN)6]3– (M = Cr, Fe), and octacyanidometallates, [MV(CN)8]3– (M = Mo, W), employed with the specific compartmental ligands are able to engage anisotropic lanthanide­(III) centers, such as TbIII and DyIII, into hetero-trimetallic coordination assemblies revealing SMM or SCM character.

Cyanide d-block metal complexes were found to be good sensitizers for 4f metal ions as exemplified by linear dicyanidometallates, [MI(CN)2]- (M = Ag, Au), and square planar tetracyanidometallates, [MII(CN)4]2- (M = Pd, Pt), efficiently enhancing visible luminescence of Eu3+ or Tb3+ by metal-to-metal energy transfer process. On the contrary, low-lying charge transfer states of heteroligand tetracyanidometallates, [MII(CN)4(L)]2- (M = Ru, Os) are suitable for sensitization of near-infrared emission of Nd3+ and Yb3+. Polycyanidometallates were also explored as molecular components for magnetically anisotropic systems revealing single-molecule magnet (SMM), or analogous single-chain magnet (SCM), behavior, within heterometallic d-d, and d-f coordination systems. In particular, paramagnetic hexacyanidometallates, [MIII(CN)6]3- (M = Cr, Fe), and octacyanidometallates, [MV(CN)8]3- (M = Mo, W), employed with the specific compartmental ligands are able to engage anisotropic lanthanide(III) centers, such as TbIII and DyIII, into hetero-trimetallic coordination assemblies revealing SMM or SCM character.

elements.content: In this context, we have lately shown that polycyanidometallates can be useful for synthesis of bifunctional magnetoluminescent systems. We have selected the diamagnetic hexacyanidocobaltate­(III), [CoIII(CN)6]3–, which is red-emissive because of its d–d electronic transition, and can reasonably sensitize visible and near-infrared light emission of lanthanides by metal-to-metal energy transfer. By combining [CoIII(CN)6]3– with various 4f metal ions, including yellow-to-white-emissive Dy3+, green-emissive Tb3+, and NIR luminescent Nd3+ and Yb3+, we prepared a series of cyanido-bridged d–f coordination assemblies showing diverse luminescent effects, such as sensitized white light emission, or tunable multicolored emission, along with strong magnetic anisotropy leading to SMM behavior. We found that the crucial role in these materials is played by supporting organic ligands controlling coordination dimensionality, and coordination geometry of the 4f metal ion toward strong magnetic anisotropy.
elements.clean_text: In this context, we have lately shown that polycyanidometallates can be useful for synthesis of bifunctional magnetoluminescent systems. We have selected the diamagnetic hexacyanidocobaltate(III), [CoIII(CN)6]3-, which is red-emissive because of its d-d electronic transition, and can reasonably sensitize visible and near-infrared light emission of lanthanides by metal-to-metal energy transfer. By combining [CoIII(CN)6]3- with various 4f metal ions, including yellow-to-white-emissive Dy3+, green-emissive Tb3+, and NIR luminescent Nd3+ and Yb3+, we prepared a series of cyanido-bridged d-f coordination assemblies showing diverse luminescent effects, such as sensitized white light emission, or tunable multicolored emission, along with strong magnetic anisotropy leading to SMM behavior. We found that the crucial role in these materials is played by supporting organic ligands controlling coordination dimensionality, and coordination geometry of the 4f metal ion toward strong magnetic anisotropy.

elements.content: Taking advantage of bridging organic ligands fruitfully employed in functional MOFs, and the latest application of the [CoIII(CN)6]3– ion for creating lanthanide-based emissive SMMs, we have decided to apply both organic and inorganic linkers for construction of bifunctional magnetic and luminescent d–f coordination networks. In our first report, we have shown the hybrid organic–inorganic NdIII(pyrazine-N,N′-dioxide)­[CoIII(CN)6]3– chains with implemented nine-coordinated NdIII complexes exhibiting near-infrared emission and field-induced slow magnetic relaxation. To construct highly dimensional magnetoluminescent coordination frameworks, we have tested various organic ligands from the family of N-oxides of pyridine derivatives, which exhibit the great affinity toward 4f metal ions, including lanthanide­(III)–[MIII(CN)6]3– (M = Co, Fe) coordination systems. Among many pyridine derivatives broadly applied for functional cyanido-bridged assemblies, we decided to employ the rare O,O-bidentate bridging 4,4′-azopyridine-1,1′-dioxide (apdo) ligand. Its strong visible light absorption, related to the presence of pyridineNNpyridine chromophoric system, is of a special interest in sensitization of lanthanide NIR emission, strongly desired for applications in telecommunication, bioanalyses, and solar energy conversion. Therefore, we present the synthesis, crystal structure, and detailed magnetic and optical studies of a unique family of crystalline functional materials based on hybrid [{LnIII(apdo)­(H2O)4}­{CoIII(CN)6}]·2H2O (Ln = Nd, 1; Tb, 2; Dy, 3; Er, 4; Tm, 5; Yb, 6) layered frameworks built by Ln–cyanide–Co and Ln–apdo–Ln molecular bridges, which exhibit complex field-induced slow magnetic relaxation, and sensitized near-infrared luminescence.

In our first report, we have shown the hybrid organic-inorganic NdIII(pyrazine-N,N'-dioxide)[CoIII(CN)6]3- chains with implemented nine-coordinated NdIII complexes exhibiting near-infrared emission and field-induced slow magnetic relaxation. elements.content: Lanthanide precursors of a high purity (>99%), including neodymium­(III) chloride hexahydrate (NdCl3·6H2O), terbium­(III) chloride hexahydrate (TbCl3·6H2O), dysprosium­(III) chloride hexahydrate (DyCl3·6H2O), erbium­(III) chloride hexahydrate (ErCl3·6H2O), thulium­(III) chloride hexahydrate (TmCl3·6H2O), ytterbium­(III) chloride hexahydrate (YbCl3·6H2O), and cyanide precursor, potassium hexacyanidocobaltate­(III) (K3[Co­(CN)6]), were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. The starting materials for the synthesis of organic ligand, 4-nitropyridine N-oxide, and sodium borohydride were received from Sigma-Aldrich, and used without further purification.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials

Lanthanide precursors of a high purity (>99%), including neodymium(III) chloride hexahydrate (NdCl3⋅6H2O), terbium(III) chloride hexahydrate (TbCl3⋅6H2O), dysprosium(III) chloride hexahydrate (DyCl3⋅6H2O), erbium(III) chloride hexahydrate (ErCl3⋅6H2O), thulium(III) chloride hexahydrate (TmCl3⋅6H2O), ytterbium(III) chloride hexahydrate (YbCl3⋅6H2O), and cyanide precursor, potassium hexacyanidocobaltate(III) (K3[Co(CN)6]), were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. The starting materials for the synthesis of organic ligand, 4-nitropyridine N-oxide, and sodium borohydride were received from Sigma-Aldrich, and used without further purification.

elements.content: The organic ligand, 4,4′-azopyridine-1,1′-dioxide (apdo), was prepared within the modified literature procedure. Under the optimized conditions, the apdo ligand was prepared as follows. A 4.23 g (0.03 mol) portion of 4-nitropyridine N-oxide was dissolved in 300 mL of distilled water. A 1.13 g (0.03 mol) portion of sodium borohydride dissolved in 300 mL of water was slowly added to the resulting solution, with continuous intensive stirring of the mixture. The reaction was conducted through the next 24 h, which led to the gradual change of the solution color from yellow to deep red. The resulting mixture was left for slow evaporation in the air for ca. 2 weeks. After that, the large amount of deep red crystals were gathered by suction filtration, and recrystallized from ethanol, and later acetone. Yield: 1.9 g (60%). The purity of the obtained product was checked by IR absorption spectra compared with the literature report. In addition, we have performed the 1H NMR experiment of the apdo product dissolved in the CDCl3 solvent. The characteristic peaks at chemical shifts of 7.84 and 8.29 ppm were observed, and they are in a good agreement with the reported values. The other very weak peaks appeared at 8.12 and 8.26 ppm, and they are due to the unknown impurities; thus, the apdo purity of ca. 90% was postulated. To verify if these impurities influence the crystallization of the coordination compounds, 1–6, we have purchased a small amount of the apdo ligand from Sigma-Aldrich (95% of purity, product no. S446742), and we have repeated the synthesis of 1 (see below). We obtained the identical crystals of 1 as verified by the single-crystal X-ray diffraction method which proved that the impurities appearing during our preparation of the apdo ligand do not influence the crystallization of the final coordination frameworks.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of 4,4'-Azopyridine-1,1'-dioxide (apdo)

The organic ligand, 4,4'-azopyridine-1,1'-dioxide (apdo), was prepared within the modified literature procedure. Under the optimized conditions, the apdo ligand was prepared as follows. A 4.23 g (0.03 mol) portion of 4-nitropyridine N-oxide was dissolved in 300 mL of distilled water. A 1.13 g (0.03 mol) portion of sodium borohydride dissolved in 300 mL of water was slowly added to the resulting solution, with continuous intensive stirring of the mixture. The reaction was conducted through the next 24 h, which led to the gradual change of the solution color from yellow to deep red. The resulting mixture was left for slow evaporation in the air for ca. 2 weeks. After that, the large amount of deep red crystals were gathered by suction filtration, and recrystallized from ethanol, and later acetone. Yield: 1.9 g (60%). The purity of the obtained product was checked by IR absorption spectra compared with the literature report. In addition, we have performed the 1H NMR experiment of the apdo product dissolved in the CDCl3 solvent. The characteristic peaks at chemical shifts of 7.84 and 8.29 ppm were observed, and they are in a good agreement with the reported values. The other very weak peaks appeared at 8.12 and 8.26 ppm, and they are due to the unknown impurities; thus, the apdo purity of ca. 90% was postulated. To verify if these impurities influence the crystallization of the coordination compounds, 1-6, we have purchased a small amount of the apdo ligand from Sigma-Aldrich (95% of purity, product no. S446742), and we have repeated the synthesis of 1 (see below). We obtained the identical crystals of 1 as verified by the single-crystal X-ray diffraction method which proved that the impurities appearing during our preparation of the apdo ligand do not influence the crystallization of the final coordination frameworks.

elements.content: All compounds, 1–6, were prepared in an analogous manner using the following procedure. A 0.12 mmol portion of the appropriate lanthanide­(III) chloride hexahydrate and 0.12 mmol of apdo were added together to 1.5 mL of distilled water. The resulting suspension was heated to the boiling point with stirring to obtain the clear red solution. This solution was added to the freshly prepared yellowish solution of 0.12 mmol of potassium hexacyanocobaltate­(III) in 0.5 mL of distilled water. The mixing of these two solutions resulted in the precipitation of the orange powder which was separated by a suction filtration. The clear red filtrate was left for crystallization in the darkness. After 1 week, red platelet crystals of the compounds, 1–6, were collected, washed with water and methanol, and dried in the air to obtain crystalline materials with good stability under ambient conditions. All the applied lanthanides resulted in the crystalline products with the analogous formula, [{LnIII(apdo)­(H2O)4}­{CoIII(CN)6}]·2H2O (Ln = Nd, 1; Tb, 2; Dy, 3; Er, 4; Tm, 5; Yb, 6), as determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis supported by the CHN elemental analysis (see below), IR absorption spectra showing the presence of organic ligand and cyanides (Figure S1, Supporting Information), and thermogravimetric studies (Figure S2, Supporting Information). Synthetic yields ranged between 30% and 50% depending on the lanthanide and length of the crystallization time. [{NdIII(apdo)­(H2O)4}­{CoIII(CN)6}]·2H2O (1). Anal. Calcd for Nd1Co1C16H20N10O8 (M W = 683.6 g mol–1): C, 28,1%; H, 2.9%; N, 20.5%. Found: C, 27.9%; H, 2.9%; N, 20.5%. IR spectrum (cm–1). CN– stretching vibrations: 2094w, 2107w, 2124sh, 2137s, 2146sh, 2154m, 2167m. [{TbIII(apdo)­(H2O)4}­{CoIII(CN)6}]·2H2O (2). Anal. Calcd for Tb1Co1C16H20N10O8 (M W = 698.2 g mol–1): C, 27.5%; H, 2.9%; N, 20.1%. Found: C, 27.2%; H, 2.9%; N, 19.9%. IR spectrum (cm–1). CN– stretching vibrations: 2096w, 2110w, 2127sh, 2138s, 2147sh, 2159m, 2169m. [{DyIII(apdo)­(H2O)4}­{CoIII(CN)6}]·2H2O (3). Anal. Calcd for Dy1Co1C16H20N10O8 (M W = 701.8 g mol–1): C, 27.4%; H, 2.9%; N, 20.0%. Found: C, 27.2%; H, 2.9%; N, 19.7%. IR spectrum (cm–1). CN– stretching vibrations: 2097w, 2113w, 2127sh, 2139s, 2148sh, 2160m, 2170m. [{ErIII(apdo)­(H2O)4}­{CoIII(CN)6}]·2H2O (4). Anal. Calcd for Tm1Co1C16H20N10O8 (M W = 708.3 g mol–1): C, 27.1%; H, 2.8%; N, 19.8%. Found: C, 26.8%; H, 2.8%; N, 19.6%. IR spectrum (cm–1). CN– stretching vibrations: 2097w, 2114w, 2130sh, 2140s, 2148sh, 2163m, 2174m. [{YbIII(apdo)­(H2O)4}­{CoIII(CN)6}]·2H2O (6). Anal. Calcd for Yb1Co1C16H20N10O8 (M W = 712.4 g mol–1): C, 27.0%; H, 2.8%; N, 19.7%. Found: C, 26.8%; H, 2.8%; N, 19.7%. IR spectrum (cm–1). CN– stretching vibrations: 2098w, 2114w, 2129sh, 2140s, 2149sh, 2163m, 2172m.

Synthetic Procedures for 1-6 

All compounds, 1-6, were prepared in an analogous manner using the following procedure. A 0.12 mmol portion of the appropriate lanthanide(III) chloride hexahydrate and 0.12 mmol of apdo were added together to 1.5 mL of distilled water. The resulting suspension was heated to the boiling point with stirring to obtain the clear red solution. This solution was added to the freshly prepared yellowish solution of 0.12 mmol of potassium hexacyanocobaltate(III) in 0.5 mL of distilled water. The mixing of these two solutions resulted in the precipitation of the orange powder which was separated by a suction filtration. The clear red filtrate was left for crystallization in the darkness. After 1 week, red platelet crystals of the compounds, 1-6, were collected, washed with water and methanol, and dried in the air to obtain crystalline materials with good stability under ambient conditions. All the applied lanthanides resulted in the crystalline products with the analogous formula, [{LnIII(apdo)(H2O)4}{CoIII(CN)6}]⋅2H2O (Ln = Nd, 1; Tb, 2; Dy, 3; Er, 4; Tm, 5; Yb, 6), as determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis supported by the CHN elemental analysis (see below), IR absorption spectra showing the presence of organic ligand and cyanides (Figure S1, Supporting Information), and thermogravimetric studies (Figure S2, Supporting Information). Synthetic yields ranged between 30% and 50% depending on the lanthanide and length of the crystallization time. [{NdIII(apdo)(H2O)4}{CoIII(CN)6}]⋅2H2O (1). Anal. Calcd for Nd1Co1C16H20N10O8 (M W = 683.6 g mol-1): C, 28,1%; H, 2.9%; N, 20.5%. Found: C, 27.9%; H, 2.9%; N, 20.5%. IR spectrum (cm-1). CN- stretching vibrations: 2094w, 2107w, 2124sh, 2137s, 2146sh, 2154m, 2167m. [{TbIII(apdo)(H2O)4}{CoIII(CN)6}]⋅2H2O (2). Anal. Calcd for Dy1Co1C16H20N10O8 (M W = 701.8 g mol-1): C, 27.4%; H, 2.9%; N, 20.0%. Found: C, 27.2%; H, 2.9%; N, 19.7%. IR spectrum (cm-1). CN- stretching vibrations: 2097w, 2113w, 2127sh, 2139s, 2148sh, 2160m, 2170m. [{ErIII(apdo)(H2O)4}{CoIII(CN)6}]⋅2H2O (4). Anal. Calcd for Er1Co1C16H20N10O8 (M W = 706.6 g mol-1): C, 27.2%; H, 2.8%; N, 19.8%. Found: C, 26.8%; H, 2.8%; N, 19.7%. IR spectrum (cm-1). elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses were performed for 1–6 using a Bruker D8 Quest Eco Photon50 CMOS diffractometer with Mo Kα radiation. The single crystals were selected from the mother solution, dispersed in Apiezon N grease, mounted on a Micro Mounts holder, and measured at 298(2) K. Data reduction and cell refinement were executed using SAINT and SADABS programs. The multiscan procedure was applied to perform absorption correction. Crystal structures were solved using an intrinsic phasing method of the SHELXT program. The further refinement was done using a weighted full-matrix least-squares method on SHELX-2014/7. Anisotropic refinement was applied for all non-hydrogen atoms. The positions of hydrogen atoms were found for an electron density map, and refined isotropically. A riding model was used for the thermal ellipsoids of hydrogen atoms belonging to water molecules. The positions of all the hydrogen atoms were restrained by using the DFIX commands for the respective O–H, C–H, and some H–H distances to ensure the proper geometry, and keep the convergence of the refinement process. Details of crystal data and structure refinement for the crystal structures of all reported compounds, 1–6, are presented in . The structural data were deposited in the CCDC database; the reference numbers are 1855280–1855285.

The single crystals were selected from the mother solution, dispersed in Apiezon N grease, mounted on a Micro Mounts holder, and measured at 298(2) K. Crystal structures were solved using an intrinsic phasing method of the SHELXT program. The further refinement was done using a weighted full-matrix least-squares method on SHELX-2014/7. Anisotropic refinement was applied for all non-hydrogen atoms. The positions of hydrogen atoms were found for an electron density map, and refined isotropically. A riding model was used for the thermal ellipsoids of hydrogen atoms belonging to water molecules. The positions of all the hydrogen atoms were restrained by using the DFIX commands for the respective O-H, C-H, and some H-H distances to ensure the proper geometry, and keep the convergence of the refinement process. Details of crystal data and structure refinement for the crystal structures of all reported compounds, 1-6, are presented in . Infrared absorption spectra were measured on the selected single crystals using a Nicolet iN10 MX FTIR microscope. The 1H NMR spectrum for the apdo ligand was measured using the NMR Avance III 600 MHz spectrometer (Bruker). Thermogravimetric curves were gathered for the polycrystalline samples using a Rigaku Thermo Plus TG8120 apparatus with aluminum oxide as a reference material. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns were obtained on the carefully ground polycrystalline samples using a Rigaku Ultima-IV diffractometer equipped with Cu Kα radiation. Magnetic properties of 1–3 were investigated by using a Quantum Design MPMS-3 Evercool magnetometer while those of 4–6 were investigated by using a Quantum Design MPMS XL magnetometer. The polycrystalline samples for magnetic measurements were ground and pressed into pellets to avoid the rotation of crystals under an applied magnetic field. They were additionally covered by a Kapton tape, and fixed on a quartz stick, later inserted into the magnetometer. Magnetic data were corrected for the diamagnetic contributions from the sample, and the sample holder. UV–vis–NIR absorption spectra were gathered in a transmission mode for the thin films of polycrystalline samples dispersed between two quartz plates, by using a PerkinElmer Lambda 35 spectrophotometer.
elements.clean_text:
Physical Techniques

Infrared absorption spectra were measured on the selected single crystals using a Nicolet iN10 MX FTIR microscope. The 1H NMR spectrum for the apdo ligand was measured using the NMR Avance III 600 MHz spectrometer (Bruker). Thermogravimetric curves were gathered for the polycrystalline samples using a Rigaku Thermo Plus TG8120 apparatus with aluminum oxide as a reference material. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns were obtained on the carefully ground polycrystalline samples using a Rigaku Ultima-IV diffractometer equipped with Cu Kα radiation. Magnetic properties of 1-3 were investigated by using a Quantum Design MPMS-3 Evercool magnetometer while those of 4-6 were investigated by using a Quantum Design MPMS XL magnetometer. The polycrystalline samples for magnetic measurements were ground and pressed into pellets to avoid the rotation of crystals under an applied magnetic field. They were additionally covered by a Kapton tape, and fixed on a quartz stick, later inserted into the magnetometer. Magnetic data were corrected for the diamagnetic contributions from the sample, and the sample holder. UV-vis-NIR absorption spectra were gathered in a transmission mode for the thin films of polycrystalline samples dispersed between two quartz plates, by using a PerkinElmer Lambda 35 spectrophotometer.

elements.content: Solid state photoluminescent characteristics, including emission and excitation spectra, were collected at liquid-nitrogen temperature by using a Horiba Jobin Yvon Fluorolog-3 (FL3-211) spectrofluorimeter equipped with a Xe (450 W) lamp, a room-temperature R928P emission detector operating in a photocounting mode for the UV–vis range, and a liquid-nitrogen-cooled InGaAs photodiode detector DSS-IGA020L for the NIR range. The emission and excitation spectra were corrected for the apparatus response, and analyzed using FluorEssence software.
elements.clean_text: Solid state photoluminescent characteristics, including emission and excitation spectra, were collected at liquid-nitrogen temperature by using a Horiba Jobin Yvon Fluorolog-3 (FL3-211) spectrofluorimeter equipped with a Xe (450 W) lamp, a room-temperature R928P emission detector operating in a photocounting mode for the UV-vis range, and a liquid-nitrogen-cooled InGaAs photodiode detector DSS-IGA020L for the NIR range. The emission and excitation spectra were corrected for the apparatus response, and analyzed using FluorEssence software.

elements.content: Red platelet single crystals of 1–6 were obtained by the spontaneous crystallization from the water solution containing equimolar portions of K3[Co­(CN)6], 4,4′-azopyridine-1,1′-dioxide (apdo), and chloride of the appropriate lanthanide­(III) (see the for details). The crystalline samples of 1–6 were preliminarily characterized by infrared absorption spectra, CHN elemental analysis, and thermogravimetric method (Figures S1 and S2). Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis was successfully performed for the selected crystals of all compounds, 1–6, and it indicated that they are isostructural, crystallizing in the identical triclinic P1̅ space group (). The representative structural views of 1 are gathered in , while the comparison of crystal structures of 1–6 is presented in Figure S3 and Table S1. Compound 1 is constructed of cyanido-bridged {Nd2Co2} squares which are further connected by Nd–apdo–Nd bridges into a two-dimensional coordination network (a). The resulting layers reveal a mixed 4- and 8-metal ring topology combining the inorganic tetrametallic {Nd2Co2(CN)4}, and the hybrid octametallic {Nd6Co2(CN)4(apdo)4} rings with apdo and cyanide bridges. The Co complex exhibits a typical octahedral geometry with six-coordinated cyanides, among which two ligands, aligned in the cis configuration, are bridging to the neighboring NdIII centers. The Nd complex coordinates two N-atoms of bridging cyanides, two O-atoms of bridging apdo ligands, and four aqua ligands, which produce eight-coordinated dodecahedral [LnIII(μ-apdo)2(H2O)4(μ-NC)2]+ moieties (b and Table S2). The coordination layers of 1 are strongly corrugated as the cyanido-bridged squares are deviated by 60° from the plane of apdo ligands (c). The interlayer space is occupied by crystallization water molecules, and the whole supramolecular network is stabilized by numerous hydrogen bonds involving terminal cyanides, as well as both coordinated and crystallization aqua ligands (Figures S4 and S5, and Table S3).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structural Studies

Red platelet single crystals of 1-6 were obtained by the spontaneous crystallization from the water solution containing equimolar portions of K3[Co(CN)6], 4,4'-azopyridine-1,1'-dioxide (apdo), and chloride of the appropriate lanthanide(III) (see the  for details). The crystalline samples of 1-6 were preliminarily characterized by infrared absorption spectra, CHN elemental analysis, and thermogravimetric method (Figures S1 and S2). Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis was successfully performed for the selected crystals of all compounds, 1-6, and it indicated that they are isostructural, crystallizing in the identical triclinic P1̅ space group (). The representative structural views of 1 are gathered in , while the comparison of crystal structures of 1-6 is presented in Figure S3 and Table S1. Compound 1 is constructed of cyanido-bridged {Nd2Co2} squares which are further connected by Nd-apdo-Nd bridges into a two-dimensional coordination network (a). The resulting layers reveal a mixed 4- and 8-metal ring topology combining the inorganic tetrametallic {Nd2Co2(CN)4}, and the hybrid octametallic {Nd6Co2(CN)4(apdo)4} rings with apdo and cyanide bridges. The Co complex exhibits a typical octahedral geometry with six-coordinated cyanides, among which two ligands, aligned in the cis configuration, are bridging to the neighboring NdIII centers. The Nd complex coordinates two N-atoms of bridging cyanides, two O-atoms of bridging apdo ligands, and four aqua ligands, which produce eight-coordinated dodecahedral [LnIII(μ-apdo)2(H2O)4(μ-NC)2]+ moieties (b and Table S2). The coordination layers of 1 are strongly corrugated as the cyanido-bridged squares are deviated by 60° from the plane of apdo ligands (c). The interlayer space is occupied by crystallization water molecules, and the whole supramolecular network is stabilized by numerous hydrogen bonds involving terminal cyanides, as well as both coordinated and crystallization aqua ligands (Figures S4 and S5, and Table S3).

elements.content: The single-crystal X-ray diffraction technique was also applied to determine the crystal structures of 2–6, and the related data indicate perfect isostructurality of these compounds with 1 (, and Figure S1, and Tables S1–S3). The metric parameters are slightly modulated on going from NdIII-containing 1, through intermediate lanthanides, to YbIII-containing 6; that is, the unit cell becomes smaller, which can be assigned to gradually smaller ionic radius, and bond lengths within the lanthanide series. Despite these changes, crystal structures, including the eight-coordinated 4f metal complexes, remain identical for all investigated compounds. It is a rare effect among lanthanide-based coordination networks, especially those based on polycyanidometallates, as usually the decrease of their ionic radius on going from NdIII to YbIII results in the decrease of coordination number, and change of the crystalline phase. This observation proved high stability of the obtained coordination framework, insensitive to changes of 4f metal ion size.

elements.content: The structural models determined for the single crystals of 1–6 are valid for the respective polycrystalline samples as documented by the powder X-ray diffraction method (Figure S6). This, together with the results of CHN elemental analysis, showing the identical composition of the compounds with those found in the X-ray crystallographic studies, indicates that the obtained bulk samples of 1–6 are stable in the air, and reveal a high phase purity.

elements.content: Direct-current (dc) magnetic properties measured for the powder samples of 1–6 are presented in . Room-temperature molar magnetic susceptibility–temperature products, χM T, are 1.8, 12.0, 14.3, 11.2, 6.9, and 2.4 cm3 mol–1 K for 1–6, respectively. These values are very close to the 1.7, 11.8, 14.2, 11.5, 7.1, and 2.6 cm3 mol–1 K, expected for free-ion contributions of respective lanthanide­(3+) complexes with their characteristic ground multiplets. Upon cooling, the χM T gradually and slowly decreases. Such performance can be assigned to the thermal depopulation of the m J levels within the ground state multiplets, while the possible Ln–Ln magnetic coupling is rather negligible thanks to the separation of lanthanide­(III) centers by diamagnetic [Co­(CN)6]3– and apdo linkers. Magnetization versus magnetic field dependences gathered at the lowest available temperature of 1.8 K shows the featureless continuous increase without full saturation even for the high field of 50 kOe (b). This is related to the lack of magnetic transitions effects, and the presence of significant magnetic anisotropy in 1–6. The highest magnetization achieved in 1 is 1.3 μB at 50 kOe which is identical to that lately observed for the NdIII complex with an almost pure m J = ±7/2 ground state with axial anisotropy, g z factor of ca. 5. TbIII-containing 2 reveals magnetization of 4.9 μB at 50 kOe which is close to the 5.0 μB expected for TbIII magnetic moments with an effective spin of 1/2, and classical Ising anisotropy with g || = 10. Similar Ising anisotropy within a 1/2 effective spin approach may be also postulated for 3 showing the magnetization of 5.3 μB at 50 kOe, slightly higher than 5.0 μB expected for pure m J = ±15/2 ground state with g z factor of 20. ErIII-containing 4 shows magnetization of 4.9 μB at 50 kOe, while the magnetization of TmIII-containing 5 saturates at 3.5 μB, both values close to those usually observed for the magnetically isolated respective lanthanide­(3+) ions.

Magnetic Properties

Direct-current (dc) magnetic properties measured for the powder samples of 1-6 are presented in . Room-temperature molar magnetic susceptibility-temperature products, χM T, are 1.8, 12.0, 14.3, 11.2, 6.9, and 2.4 cm3 mol-1 K for 1-6, respectively. These values are very close to the 1.7, 11.8, 14.2, 11.5, 7.1, and 2.6 cm3 mol-1 K, expected for free-ion contributions of respective lanthanide(3+) complexes with their characteristic ground multiplets. Upon cooling, the χM T gradually and slowly decreases. Such performance can be assigned to the thermal depopulation of the m J levels within the ground state multiplets, while the possible Ln-Ln magnetic coupling is rather negligible thanks to the separation of lanthanide(III) centers by diamagnetic [Co(CN)6]3- and apdo linkers. Magnetization versus magnetic field dependences gathered at the lowest available temperature of 1.8 K shows the featureless continuous increase without full saturation even for the high field of 50 kOe (b). This is related to the lack of magnetic transitions effects, and the presence of significant magnetic anisotropy in 1-6. The highest magnetization achieved in 1 is 1.3 μB at 50 kOe which is identical to that lately observed for the NdIII complex with an almost pure m J = ±7/2 ground state with axial anisotropy, g  z  factor of ca. 5. TbIII-containing 2 reveals magnetization of 4.9 μB at 50 kOe which is close to the 5.0 μB expected for TbIII magnetic moments with an effective spin of 1/2, and classical Ising anisotropy with g || = 10. Similar Ising anisotropy within a 1/2 effective spin approach may be also postulated for 3 showing the magnetization of 5.3 μB at 50 kOe, slightly higher than 5.0 μB expected for pure m J = ±15/2 ground state with g  z  factor of 20. ErIII-containing 4 shows magnetization of 4.9 μB at 50 kOe, while the magnetization of TmIII-containing 5 saturates at 3.5 μB, both values close to those usually observed for the magnetically isolated respective lanthanide(3+) ions.

elements.content: The highest magnetization for 6 is 1.5 μB at 50 kOe which is visibly lower than 1.8 μB, lately detected for anisotropic YbIII embedded in octahedral geometry, and 2.0 μB calculated for the pure m J = ±7/2 ground state with axial anisotropy, g z factor of ca. 8. In summary, the observed values of magnetization at 50 kOe at 1.8 K indicate that 1–6 contain magnetically isolated lanthanide­(III) centers; however, a detailed scheme of their crystal field splittings is not easily accessible using such a simple consideration of their field dependences of magnetization.

elements.content: Taking advantage of the presence of magnetically anisotropic lanthanide­(3+) ions being in a magnetic isolation, 1–6 were investigated in the context of possible slow relaxation of magnetization effects. The related alternate-current (ac) magnetic characteristics are presented in –, , and Figures S7–S15 (Supporting Information). Under zero dc magnetic field at the lowest available temperature of 1.8 K, 1 reveals a negligibly small signal of the imaginary magnetic susceptibility, χM″, which is most probably due to the fast quantum tunneling of magnetization (QTM). However, the significant χM″ signal appears after applying even a very small dc field of 200 Oe (a). The increasing dc magnetic field induces the onset of two relaxation processes as depicted by χM″ versus ac frequency curves. Starting from 800 Oe of the dc field, the ac magnetic characteristics, including χM″(ν), χM′(ν), and Argand χM″(χM′) plots, were successfully analyzed using the generalized Debye model for two relaxation pathways (a and Figure S7). The resulting relaxation times at various dc magnetic fields are shown in b and Figure S7d. Faster relaxation depicted by the maxima close to 1000 Hz on χM″(ν) plots was found to be almost invariant with changes of the applied dc magnetic field, and it can be presumably assigned to intermolecular interactions within the coordination layers of 1, while slower relaxation, strongly field-dependent, is assigned to a single-ion relaxation within the isolated NdIII complexes. On increasing the dc magnetic field, this relaxation pathway gradually slows down which can be interpreted by terms of the reduction of quantum tunneling process by field-induced splitting of the ground state.

elements.content: Magnetic-field-variable alternate-current (ac) magnetic susceptibility of 1 at T = 1.8 K, under H ac = 1 Oe, and its analysis: (a) frequency dependences of the out-of-phase susceptibility, χM″, at various indicated dc external magnetic fields, and (b) the field dependence of the relaxation time, τ. Both field and relaxation times were presented in part b in the logarithmic scale. The relaxation times were only shown for the faster field-dependent relaxation. Colored solid curves in part a represent the best fits using the generalized Debye model for two relaxation processes. The solid red line in part b shows the best fit taking into account quantum tunneling of magnetization, and direct process for the range 800–8000 Oe.

elements.content: The resulting high B 1 indicates the dominance of the QTM effect, which is a good agreement with the high H dc of 4500 Oe, necessary to induce the slowest accessible magnetic relaxation. For this optimal dc field, the full temperature-variable ac magnetic characteristics were collected, and they clearly depict field-induced slow magnetic relaxation of 1 ( and Figure S8). The ac magnetic plots, and the related Argand plots, corresponding to the 1.8–3.5 K range, were analyzed using the generalized Debye model for two relaxation phenomena (a). Similarly to the field dependence at 1.8 K, the relaxation times of the faster relaxation process are not significantly sensitive to changes of temperature, when slower relaxation is strongly temperature-dependent (b and Figure S8d). For a limited, higher-temperature range 3.0–3.5 K, the ln­(τ) versus T –1 plot for the slower relaxation process could be reproduced by using the classical Arrhenius law for thermally activated magnetic relaxation, . ln ( τ ) = Δ E k B T + ln ( τ 0 ) Here, ΔE/k B is an effective thermal energy, and τ0 is a microscopic attempt time, interpreted as the relaxation attempt time for spin reversal at infinite temperature (b). The resulting best-fit parameters of ΔE/k B = 12(1) K with τ0 = 1.5(2) × 10–5 s indicate the field-induced single-molecule magnet character of NdIII complexes embedded within the coordination layers of 1. At lower temperatures below 3 K, the relaxation time deviates from the typical Arrhenius-type dependence which originates from the onset of various additional relaxation pathways. Two of them, QTM and direct processes, have been already recognized by analysis of field dependence of relaxation time (). In addition, the “through-barrier” Raman processes are expected to operate. They are strongly temperature-dependent, being proportional to T n , where n can be situated within the limit of 1–6 for 4f metal ions if optical and acoustic phonons are considered. Taking into account all contributions, global relaxation time can be depicted by . τ − 1 = A d i r T H 4 + B 1 1 + B 2 H 2 + B R a m a n T n + τ 0 − 1 exp ( − Δ E k B T ) Here, the four terms show the direct process, QTM, Raman, and Orbach relaxations, respectively. For the avoidance of overparametrization, the parameters describing direct process (A dir) and QTM effect (B 1, B 2) were taken from the field dependence of relaxation time at 1.8 K, and the starting parameters for the Orbach relaxation were taken from the fitting following the Arrhenius law. With these restrictions, the relaxation time, τ, was successfully fitted using , giving the set of parameters collected in . Obtained values of ΔE/k B = 15.1(9) K with τ0 = 9.8(9) × 10–6 s of the Orbach contribution confirm the SMM character of 1, while small B Raman = 7.5(8) s–1 K–1 with the reasonable n = 3.2(9) indicates relatively weak contribution of Raman processes and, thus, dominance of QTM at low temperatures, and a two-phonon Orbach process at higher temperatures.

elements.content: Significant field-induced slow magnetic relaxation of a single-ion origin was found for DyIII-containing 3 ( and , and Figures S9 and S10). At zero dc field at 1.8 K, there is a visible onset of the signal on the χM″(ν) plot, suggesting that this compound shows even zero dc field magnetic relaxation; however, this process is too fast, and the related maxima are out of the available frequency range above 1000 Hz (a). Magnetic relaxation significantly slows down on applying the dc field, and the resulting ac magnetic characteristics could be fitted by using the generalized Debye model for the dc fields above 300 Oe. For the whole range of magnetic fields up to 5000 Oe, the ac magnetic curves were fitted using the model for two relaxation pathways. Similarly to 1, faster relaxation in 3, depicted by the relaxation times close to 0.1 ms, is not dependent on the applied magnetic field; thus, it is not assigned to a typical single-ion property (Figure S9d). On the contrary, the slower relaxation process depends strongly on the dc magnetic field, and the related field-dependent relaxation time could be fitted using (b, ). The obtained B 1 parameter is much smaller than in 1, which together with the increase of B 2 suggests the weaker QTM effect, and results in a much smaller optimal dc field of 1500 Oe. Under these optimized conditions, we have collected the full set of temperature-variable ac magnetic characteristics, which indicate clearly the presence of field-induced slow magnetic relaxation with two distinguishable relaxation pathways ( and Figure S10). Therefore, the generalized Debye model for two relaxation processes was applied. The faster relaxation is not temperature-dependent; thus, it originates probably from intermolecular interactions, while the slower one reveals typically significant changes with temperature (Figure S10d). Within the higher-temperature range 4.0–4.6 K, the obtained relaxation time obeys the Arrhenius law (), resulting in the effective thermal energy barrier of ΔE/k B = 14.5(7) K with τ0 = 9.3(5) × 10–5 s, similar to those observed in 1. Below 4 K, the other spin-reversal pathways start to operate; thus, the ln­(τ) versus T –1 plot deviates strongly from linearity. The temperature dependence of relaxation time for the full available range 1.8–4.6 K could be fitted by using , taking into account the QTM effect, direct process, Raman relaxation, and Orbach thermal relaxation through an energy barrier (d, ). In addition to the QTM effect and direct process, already found from the field-dependent ac magnetic data, 3 reveals the very small Raman relaxation, and Orbach thermal relaxation effect depicted by parameters of ΔE/k B = 16.1(8) K with τ0 = 9.0(9) × 10–5 s, indicating a field-induced single-molecule magnet character of DyIII complexes of 3.

Magnetic relaxation significantly slows down on applying the dc field, and the resulting ac magnetic characteristics could be fitted by using the generalized Debye model for the dc fields above 300 Oe. For the whole range of magnetic fields up to 5000 Oe, the ac magnetic curves were fitted using the model for two relaxation pathways. Similarly to 1, faster relaxation in 3, depicted by the relaxation times close to 0.1 ms, is not dependent on the applied magnetic field; thus, it is not assigned to a typical single-ion property (Figure S9d). On the contrary, the slower relaxation process depends strongly on the dc magnetic field, and the related field-dependent relaxation time could be fitted using  (b, ). The obtained B 1 parameter is much smaller than in 1, which together with the increase of B 2 suggests the weaker QTM effect, and results in a much smaller optimal dc field of 1500 Oe. Under these optimized conditions, we have collected the full set of temperature-variable ac magnetic characteristics, which indicate clearly the presence of field-induced slow magnetic relaxation with two distinguishable relaxation pathways ( and Figure S10). Therefore, the generalized Debye model for two relaxation processes was applied. The faster relaxation is not temperature-dependent; thus, it originates probably from intermolecular interactions, while the slower one reveals typically significant changes with temperature (Figure S10d). Within the higher-temperature range 4.0-4.6 K, the obtained relaxation time obeys the Arrhenius law (), resulting in the effective thermal energy barrier of ΔE/k B = 14.5(7) K with τ0 = 9.3(5) × 10-5 s, similar to those observed in 1. Below 4 K, the other spin-reversal pathways start to operate; thus, the ln(τ) versus T -1 plot deviates strongly from linearity. The temperature dependence of relaxation time for the full available range 1.8-4.6 K could be fitted by using , taking into account the QTM effect, direct process, Raman relaxation, and Orbach thermal relaxation through an energy barrier (d, ). In addition to the QTM effect and direct process, already found from the field-dependent ac magnetic data, 3 reveals the very small Raman relaxation, and Orbach thermal relaxation effect depicted by parameters of ΔE/k B = 16.1(8) K with τ0 = 9.0(9) × 10-5 s, indicating a field-induced single-molecule magnet character of DyIII complexes of 3.

elements.content: The complex magnetic relaxation scheme was also detected for YbIII-containing compound 6 ( and , and Figures S11 and S12). It does not exhibit zero dc field slow magnetic relaxation due to the QTM effect, but it is overcome after applying even a tiny external magnetic field of 100 Oe (a). On the contrary to 1 and 3, the field-induced ac magnetic curves in 6 could be fitted using the generalized Debye model for a single relaxation, at least for the low-field region below 1000 Oe. Higher magnetic fields induce some additional slow magnetic relaxation process appearing at very low frequencies, but it gives only a minor contribution; thus, it was not analyzed in detail. On increasing the dc field, faster relaxation is first slowed down because of the canceling of QTM, and further accelerated by the onset of the direct relaxation effect. Following , we found a relatively large B 1 parameter describing QTM, but this effect is overcome by the significant A dir parameter of a direct process (). As a result, the small optimal dc field of 700 Oe was observed, and it was selected for the full temperature-variable ac magnetic studies ( and Figure S12). For the whole range of temperatures, a clear single relaxation process was detected, and it was analyzed using the Debye model up to 4.6 K. The resulting relaxation time obeys the Arrhenius law () within the higher-temperature region 4.0–4.6 K, indicating the effective thermal energy barrier of 15.4(4) K with τ0 of 3.1(5) × 10–6 s, lying within the limits typical for single-molecule magnet systems. The other relaxation effects, including QTM and direct processes, and Raman relaxation, are responsible for deviation of the ln­(τ) versus T –1 plot from linearity, and they were fitted using (d and ). The resulting B Raman parameter of 30(2) s–1 K–1 is much higher than those found in 1 and 3, suggesting the stronger contribution of Raman processes within the coordination network of 6, while the Orbach thermal relaxation with ΔE/k B = 17.3(6) K confirms the SMM character of YbIII complexes in 6.

elements.content: Both field- and temperature-variable ac magnetic data were also gathered for compounds 2, 4, and 5, and they are presented in Figures S13–S15, respectively. In all of these systems, there are field-induced signals on the χM″(ν) plots, and they are strongly dependent on the strength of applied dc magnetic field. However, these relaxation processes measured for the selected dc fields of 1500, 800, and 4000 Oe, for 2, 4, and 5, respectively, were found to be independent of temperature; thus, they cannot be assigned to the single-ion properties of the respective lanthanide­(3+) ions.

elements.content: Solid state optical properties of 1–6 were investigated by means of absorption, emission, and excitation spectra presented in and , and Figures S16 and S17. All compounds exhibit a deep red color related to the electronic absorption from the UV part of the spectrum toward the visible region up to ca. 500 nm, with the non-negligible absorption tail going to 600 nm (Figure S16). Absorption properties of 1–6 are very similar because they mainly originate from electronic transitions within [CoIII(CN)6]3– ions and apdo ligands. The role of the lanthanide ion is rather minor, as only 1 exhibits a series of weak peaks in the visible and near-infrared range, which can be ascribed to NdIII-centered f–f electronic transitions (Figure S16a). Strong UV absorption of 1–6 is related to the numerous spin-allowed singlet–singlet π–π* electronic transitions of apdo, and the weaker but non-negligible contribution from a series of d–d electronic transitions of hexacyanidocobaltate­(III) ions. They include both spin-allowed 1A1g → 1Eg, 1A1g → 1T2g, and 1A1g → 1T1g transitions, as well as the spin-forbidden 1A1g → 3T1g transition, expected at ca. 210, 250, 315, and 390 nm, respectively (Figure S16). The singlet–singlet π–π* electronic transitions of apdo are also responsible for the strong visible light absorption, in particular in the 450–580 nm range, where [Co­(CN)6]3– and 4f metal ions are almost transparent.
elements.clean_text:
Optical Properties

Solid state optical properties of 1-6 were investigated by means of absorption, emission, and excitation spectra presented in  and , and Figures S16 and S17. All compounds exhibit a deep red color related to the electronic absorption from the UV part of the spectrum toward the visible region up to ca. 500 nm, with the non-negligible absorption tail going to 600 nm (Figure S16). Absorption properties of 1-6 are very similar because they mainly originate from electronic transitions within [CoIII(CN)6]3- ions and apdo ligands. The role of the lanthanide ion is rather minor, as only 1 exhibits a series of weak peaks in the visible and near-infrared range, which can be ascribed to NdIII-centered f-f electronic transitions (Figure S16a). Strong UV absorption of 1-6 is related to the numerous spin-allowed singlet-singlet π-π* electronic transitions of apdo, and the weaker but non-negligible contribution from a series of d-d electronic transitions of hexacyanidocobaltate(III) ions. They include both spin-allowed 1A1g → 1Eg, 1A1g → 1T2g, and 1A1g → 1T1g transitions, as well as the spin-forbidden 1A1g → 3T1g transition, expected at ca. 210, 250, 315, and 390 nm, respectively (Figure S16). The singlet-singlet π-π* electronic transitions of apdo are also responsible for the strong visible light absorption, in particular in the 450-580 nm range, where [Co(CN)6]3- and 4f metal ions are almost transparent.

elements.content: As a result of a broadband UV–vis absorption, the possible visible light photoluminescence of TbIII-containing 2, DyIII-containing 3, and TmIII-containing 5 is totally quenched because of the overlap of the respective emissive states with the electronic levels of the apdo ligand, leading to the self-absorption effect of the expected luminescence (Figure S17). On the contrary, NdIII-containing 1 and YbIII-containing 6 reveal the characteristic luminescent signals in the near-infrared range ( and ).
elements.clean_text: As a result of a broadband UV-vis absorption, the possible visible light photoluminescence of TbIII-containing 2, DyIII-containing 3, and TmIII-containing 5 is totally quenched because of the overlap of the respective emissive states with the electronic levels of the apdo ligand, leading to the self-absorption effect of the expected luminescence (Figure S17). On the contrary, NdIII-containing 1 and YbIII-containing 6 reveal the characteristic luminescent signals in the near-infrared range ( and ).

elements.content: Compound 1 reveals typical emission in the NIR range with two distinguishable peaks centered at 900 and 1060 nm, interpreted by means of NdIII-centered f–f transitions from the emissive 4F3/2 to the 4I9/2 and 4I11/2 electronic levels (a). This luminescence can be induced by using both UV light and visible light of various wavelengths. For instance, the representative emission peaks in 1 were gathered by using the 310 nm of UV light, that is, by excitation of [Co­(CN)6]3– and apdo, the main absorbers for this wavelength (b). The NIR emission can be also induced by the visible light of the 400–500 nm range where the apdo ligand is a dominant absorber, as well as by higher wavelengths using the selective excitation of NdIII electronic multiplets. Such interpretation is supported by the excitation spectra for the monitored 1060 nm emission, which include the broad band ranging from the UV region to ca. 550 nm, along with the further series of direct f–f excitation pathways. This indicates the presence of ligand-to-metal and metal-to-metal energy transfer processes occurring from apdo and CoIII cyanide complexes, respectively, to NdIII moieties. The efficiency of energy transfer processes in 1 is rather weak as depicted by the related broad excitation bands between 250 and 500 nm which are much smaller than the peaks of direct f–f excitation, especially those at 578 and 740 nm. This indicates that most of the excitation light taken by the strongly absorbing apdo ligand is lost due to the radiationless thermal relaxation, and only the small part if transferred to the lanthanide­(III) center, resulting in the sensitized NIR emission. However, the presence of the apdo ligand and [Co­(CN)6]3– broadens the accessible range of excitation wavelengths; thus, both UV and visible light may be fruitfully used to induce NIR photoluminescence in 1. Emission in the NIR range was also found for 6 which exhibits a distinct emission peak centered at 980 nm (). It can be ascribed to the YbIII-centered f–f electronic transition from the emissive 2F5/2 to the ground 2F7/2 multiplet. The related excitation spectrum is composed of broad UV bands assignable to both cyanide CoIII complex and the apdo ligand, and a broad band in the visible range with a long tail to ca. 600 nm, which is clearly related to the apdo ligand, the only absorber in this region (b). This, together with the disappearance of the possible red emission of [Co­(CN)6]3–, indicates the energy transfer process from the cyanide complex and organic ligand to the YbIII center. The possibly NIR luminescent ErIII centers, embedded in 4, do not reveal any emission signal, even though its emissive 4I13/2 state is situated at much lower energy than the edge of apdo absorption around 700 nm (Figure S17). Therefore, the quenching of the ErIII-containing photoluminescence, expected at a long wavelength of 1550 nm, can be ascribed to the presence of the numerous O–H oscillators related to coordinated water molecules, which were shown to be responsible for quenching of the luminescence in the low-energy NIR range.

elements.content: We report a novel family of hybrid two-dimensional coordination frameworks based on selected lanthanide­(III) (Nd, Tb, Dy, Er, Tm, Yb) centers, hexacyanidocobaltate­(III) ions, and organic O,O-bidentate 4,4′-azopyridine-1,1′-dioxide (apdo) linkers used as molecular building blocks. Application of the rarely investigated apdo ligand allowed us to achieve functional molecular materials combining important optical functionality with slow magnetic relaxation effects, both rationally designed by exploration of hybrid organic–inorganic connectivity between d- and f-block metal ions with the benefit of noninnocent organic molecules.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

We report a novel family of hybrid two-dimensional coordination frameworks based on selected lanthanide(III) (Nd, Tb, Dy, Er, Tm, Yb) centers, hexacyanidocobaltate(III) ions, and organic O,O-bidentate 4,4'-azopyridine-1,1'-dioxide (apdo) linkers used as molecular building blocks. Application of the rarely investigated apdo ligand allowed us to achieve functional molecular materials combining important optical functionality with slow magnetic relaxation effects, both rationally designed by exploration of hybrid organic-inorganic connectivity between d- and f-block metal ions with the benefit of noninnocent organic molecules.

elements.content: By embedding lanthanide­(III) centers into the distorted dodecahedral geometry, we were able to induce significant magnetic anisotropy of 4f metal complexes, including broadly investigated DyIII, as well as much less recognized NdIII and YbIII. We observed the field-induced slow magnetic relaxation effects which were analyzed taking into account multiple contributions of quantum tunneling of magnetization (QTM), direct process, Raman processes, and Orbach thermal relaxation. For three different compounds, NdCo, DyCo, and YbCo, we have shown that the relaxation processes can be explained by the separate analyses of field- and temperature-dependent ac magnetic data. From the field dependence of the ac magnetic signal, we have obtained the crucial information on QTM and direct processes, which was later utilized for convenient fitting of the full temperature dependence of magnetic relaxation times. The resulting effective thermal energy barriers of Orbach processes were found to be in the range 15–18 K with the accompanying attempt time being within the limits of 10–5–10–6 s which proved that NdIII, DyIII, and YbIII complexes, created within the skeleton, are field-induced single-molecule magnets (SMMs). Future work concerning magnetic anisotropy will include the modification of coordination topology, and the related coordination geometry around the 4f metal ion toward stronger magnetic anisotropy, by using the other N-oxides of pyridine derivatives. Moreover, the applied organic apdo ligand exhibited strong absorption in the UV region and, particularly, in the visible range by possessing a series of spin-allowed π–π* electronic transitions. As a result, the prepared materials are not good emitters of visible light, but are promising emitters of NIR emission in the case of NdCo and YbCo compounds. We have found the related distinct near-infrared photoluminescence from the respective lanthanide­(3+) ions which was realized by the Co-to-Ln metal-to-metal, and apdo-to-Ln ligand-to-metal energy transfer processes. Therefore, we have proven that the combination of hexacyanidocobalte­(III), strongly absorbing in the UV range, with the chromophoric aza-ligand of apdo, strongly absorbing in the visible range, can be a useful tool for rational design of near-infrared-emissive lanthanide-containing molecular materials showing exceptionally wide UV-to-visible excitation. In addition, for the first time in the family of cyanido-bridged d–f coordination systems, we have employed the organic ligand capable to undergo the cis–trans photoisomerization. Induction of such a process was not possible in the particular case of our compounds because of the bridging character of the apdo ligand. However, our currently ongoing work is focused on using the apdo as terminal ligand with the appropriate freedom to observe the solid state photoisomerization aimed at the manipulation of both magnetic and luminescent properties.

cln_elements.content: The organic ligand, 4,4′-azopyridine-1,1′-dioxide (apdo), was prepared within the modified literature procedure. Under the optimized conditions, the apdo ligand was prepared as follows. A 4.23 g (0.03 mol) portion of 4-nitropyridine N-oxide was dissolved in 300 mL of distilled water. A 1.13 g (0.03 mol) portion of sodium borohydride dissolved in 300 mL of water was slowly added to the resulting solution, with continuous intensive stirring of the mixture. The reaction was conducted through the next 24 h, which led to the gradual change of the solution color from yellow to deep red. The resulting mixture was left for slow evaporation in the air for ca. 2 weeks. After that, the large amount of deep red crystals were gathered by suction filtration, and recrystallized from ethanol, and later acetone. Yield: 1.9 g (60%). The purity of the obtained product was checked by IR absorption spectra compared with the literature report. In addition, we have performed the 1H NMR experiment of the apdo product dissolved in the CDCl3 solvent. The characteristic peaks at chemical shifts of 7.84 and 8.29 ppm were observed, and they are in a good agreement with the reported values. The other very weak peaks appeared at 8.12 and 8.26 ppm, and they are due to the unknown impurities; thus, the apdo purity of ca. 90% was postulated. To verify if these impurities influence the crystallization of the coordination compounds, 1–6, we have purchased a small amount of the apdo ligand from Sigma-Aldrich (95% of purity, product no. S446742), and we have repeated the synthesis of 1 (see below). We obtained the identical crystals of 1 as verified by the single-crystal X-ray diffraction method which proved that the impurities appearing during our preparation of the apdo ligand do not influence the crystallization of the final coordination frameworks.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Preparation of 4,4'-Azopyridine-1,1'-dioxide (apdo)

The organic ligand, 4,4'-azopyridine-1,1'-dioxide (apdo), was prepared within the modified literature procedure. Under the optimized conditions, the apdo ligand was prepared as follows. A 4.23 g (0.03 mol) portion of 4-nitropyridine N-oxide was dissolved in 300 mL of distilled water. A 1.13 g (0.03 mol) portion of sodium borohydride dissolved in 300 mL of water was slowly added to the resulting solution, with continuous intensive stirring of the mixture. The reaction was conducted through the next 24 h, which led to the gradual change of the solution color from yellow to deep red. The resulting mixture was left for slow evaporation in the air for ca. 2 weeks. After that, the large amount of deep red crystals were gathered by suction filtration, and recrystallized from ethanol, and later acetone. Yield: 1.9 g (60%). The purity of the obtained product was checked by IR absorption spectra compared with the literature report. In addition, we have performed the 1H NMR experiment of the apdo product dissolved in the CDCl3 solvent. The characteristic peaks at chemical shifts of 7.84 and 8.29 ppm were observed, and they are in a good agreement with the reported values. The other very weak peaks appeared at 8.12 and 8.26 ppm, and they are due to the unknown impurities; thus, the apdo purity of ca. 90% was postulated. To verify if these impurities influence the crystallization of the coordination compounds, 1-6, we have purchased a small amount of the apdo ligand from Sigma-Aldrich (95% of purity, product no. S446742), and we have repeated the synthesis of 1 (see below). We obtained the identical crystals of 1 as verified by the single-crystal X-ray diffraction method which proved that the impurities appearing during our preparation of the apdo ligand do not influence the crystallization of the final coordination frameworks.

cln_elements.content: Direct-current (dc) magnetic properties measured for the powder samples of 1–6 are presented in . Room-temperature molar magnetic susceptibility–temperature products, χM T, are 1.8, 12.0, 14.3, 11.2, 6.9, and 2.4 cm3 mol–1 K for 1–6, respectively. These values are very close to the 1.7, 11.8, 14.2, 11.5, 7.1, and 2.6 cm3 mol–1 K, expected for free-ion contributions of respective lanthanide­(3+) complexes with their characteristic ground multiplets. Upon cooling, the χM T gradually and slowly decreases. Such performance can be assigned to the thermal depopulation of the m J levels within the ground state multiplets, while the possible Ln–Ln magnetic coupling is rather negligible thanks to the separation of lanthanide­(III) centers by diamagnetic [Co­(CN)6]3– and apdo linkers. Magnetization versus magnetic field dependences gathered at the lowest available temperature of 1.8 K shows the featureless continuous increase without full saturation even for the high field of 50 kOe (b). This is related to the lack of magnetic transitions effects, and the presence of significant magnetic anisotropy in 1–6. The highest magnetization achieved in 1 is 1.3 μB at 50 kOe which is identical to that lately observed for the NdIII complex with an almost pure m J = ±7/2 ground state with axial anisotropy, g z factor of ca. 5. TbIII-containing 2 reveals magnetization of 4.9 μB at 50 kOe which is close to the 5.0 μB expected for TbIII magnetic moments with an effective spin of 1/2, and classical Ising anisotropy with g || = 10. Similar Ising anisotropy within a 1/2 effective spin approach may be also postulated for 3 showing the magnetization of 5.3 μB at 50 kOe, slightly higher than 5.0 μB expected for pure m J = ±15/2 ground state with g z factor of 20. ErIII-containing 4 shows magnetization of 4.9 μB at 50 kOe, while the magnetization of TmIII-containing 5 saturates at 3.5 μB, both values close to those usually observed for the magnetically isolated respective lanthanide­(3+) ions.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

Direct-current (dc) magnetic properties measured for the powder samples of 1-6 are presented in . Room-temperature molar magnetic susceptibility-temperature products, χM T, are 1.8, 12.0, 14.3, 11.2, 6.9, and 2.4 cm3 mol-1 K for 1-6, respectively. These values are very close to the 1.7, 11.8, 14.2, 11.5, 7.1, and 2.6 cm3 mol-1 K, expected for free-ion contributions of respective lanthanide(3+) complexes with their characteristic ground multiplets. Upon cooling, the χM T gradually and slowly decreases. Such performance can be assigned to the thermal depopulation of the m J levels within the ground state multiplets, while the possible Ln-Ln magnetic coupling is rather negligible thanks to the separation of lanthanide(III) centers by diamagnetic [Co(CN)6]3- and apdo linkers. Magnetization versus magnetic field dependences gathered at the lowest available temperature of 1.8 K shows the featureless continuous increase without full saturation even for the high field of 50 kOe (b). This is related to the lack of magnetic transitions effects, and the presence of significant magnetic anisotropy in 1-6. The highest magnetization achieved in 1 is 1.3 μB at 50 kOe which is identical to that lately observed for the NdIII complex with an almost pure m J = ±7/2 ground state with axial anisotropy, g  z  factor of ca. 5. TbIII-containing 2 reveals magnetization of 4.9 μB at 50 kOe which is close to the 5.0 μB expected for TbIII magnetic moments with an effective spin of 1/2, and classical Ising anisotropy with g || = 10. Similar Ising anisotropy within a 1/2 effective spin approach may be also postulated for 3 showing the magnetization of 5.3 μB at 50 kOe, slightly higher than 5.0 μB expected for pure m J = ±15/2 ground state with g  z  factor of 20. ErIII-containing 4 shows magnetization of 4.9 μB at 50 kOe, while the magnetization of TmIII-containing 5 saturates at 3.5 μB, both values close to those usually observed for the magnetically isolated respective lanthanide(3+) ions.

cln_elements.content: Magnetic-field-variable alternate-current (ac) magnetic susceptibility of 1 at T = 1.8 K, under H ac = 1 Oe, and its analysis: (a) frequency dependences of the out-of-phase susceptibility, χM″, at various indicated dc external magnetic fields, and (b) the field dependence of the relaxation time, τ. Both field and relaxation times were presented in part b in the logarithmic scale. The relaxation times were only shown for the faster field-dependent relaxation. Colored solid curves in part a represent the best fits using the generalized Debye model for two relaxation processes. The solid red line in part b shows the best fit taking into account quantum tunneling of magnetization, and direct process for the range 800–8000 Oe.
